question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$
inference:
The direction vectors of the two lines are
\[\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{ and } \quad \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},\]respectively.  The dot product of these two vectors is
\[\begin{aligned} \left< \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right> &= (-3)\left(-\frac{3}{2}\right) + (-2)(2) + (-6)(2) \\\ & = \frac{9}{2} - 4 - 12 \\\ & = -\frac{11}{2}. \end{aligned}\]The magnitudes of the two vectors are
\[\begin{aligned} \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| &= \sqrt{(-3)^2 + (-2)^2 + (-6)^2} = \sqrt{49} = 7, \\\ \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\| &= \sqrt{\left(-\frac{3}{2}\right)^2 + 2^2 + 2^2} = \sqrt{\frac{9}{4} + 8} = \sqrt{\frac{49}{4}} = \frac{7}{2}. \end{aligned}\]Therefore,
\[\cos \theta = \frac{\left< \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right>}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-\frac{11}{2}}{7 \cdot \frac{7}{2}} = -\frac{1}{7}.\]
Final Answer: \boxed{-\frac{1}{7}}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then
\[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$

question:
The direction vectors of the two lines are
\[\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{ and } \quad \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},\]respectively.  The dot product of these two vectors is
\[\begin{aligned} \left< \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right> &= (-3)\left(-\frac{3}{2}\right) + (-2)(2) + (-6)(2) \\\ & = \frac{9}{2} - 4 - 12 \\\ & = -\frac{11}{2}. \end{aligned}\]The magnitudes of the two vectors are
\[\begin{aligned} \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| &= \sqrt{(-3)^2 + (-2)^2 + (-6)^2} = \sqrt{49} = 7, \\\ \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\| &= \sqrt{\left(-\frac{3}{2}\right)^2 + 2^2 + 2^2} = \sqrt{\frac{9}{4} + 8} = \sqrt{\frac{49}{4}} = \frac{7}{2}. \end{aligned}\]Therefore,
\[\cos \theta = \frac{\left< \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right>}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-\frac{11}{2}}{7 \cdot \frac{7}{2}} = -\frac{1}{7}.\]
Final Answer: \boxed{-\frac{1}{7}}. I hope it is correct.

ground_truth:
The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then
\[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
